title: Tucker Carlson falsely claims that John Bolton was "The Left Man."
text: The host of Fox Tucker Carlson's news celebrated the departure of former National Security Adviser John Bolton, saying that the predatory war hawk was actually left. "If you're wondering why so many progressives mourn Bolton's shooting tonight, it's because Bolton himself was basically a man from the left," said Carlson on September 10th on his show. Carlson said that Bolton was one of the most advanced people in Trump's administration and claimed he called Obama's loyalists on the National Security Council. "There was no humanitarian problem John Bolton was not entirely convinced that could be solved by the brute power of government," said Carlson. "That's a left assumption, not a right." He added, "Don't let the mustache fool you." But it is Carlson's allegations about the former National Security Adviser that are ridiculous. (Fox News did not respond to requests for comments.) First, a note on ideologies: In the United States, we tend to link the terms "left" and "right" to the democratic and Republican parties, respectively. In this context, Carlson's claim is "unbelievable," said William Leo Grand, Professor of Government at the American University, who previously served on the Senate Committee on Democratic Policy and the House of Representatives Democratic Assembly Task Force on Central America. "It is clearly wrong to define it in terms of democratic versus republican politics," David Gartenstein Ross, Chief Executive Officer of Valins Global, a counter-terrorism consulting firm, and former adviser to the Office of Community Partnerships of the Ministry of Internal Security under the leadership of President Barack Obama and President Donald Trump. "There is no doubt that, based on the American political context, he will be considered a man of the right," said Gartenstein Ross. This is because Bolton has spent his entire career in provincial districts and served in every presidential department of the Government of the Democratic Republic of the Congo returning to President Ronald Reagan, as Leo Grand said. Here are just a few examples of Bolton's work before joining the Trump administration: in high school, Bolton volunteered for an election campaign for Republican presidential candidate Barry Goldwater, who lost to President Lyndon Johnson in the 1964 general election. • Bolton spent the summer of 1972 between classes in law schools where Vice President Spiro Agnew was trained in the administration of President Richard Nixon. • Bolton joined the Reagan Administration of the Agency for International Development (USAID) in 1981 and served as General Adviser and Year in an administrative role. Nor did we find any evidence to support Carlson's claim that Bolton "invited Obama's loyalists within the National Security Council." (NCC did not respond to requests for comments). The Washington Post and Bolescu explained in detail the dilemma that occurred after Bolton assumed the post of National Security Adviser. Many officials had left office, while others had been transferred to new roles. Bolton left some exits vacant and others filled with people outside the government. For example, Bolton Mauricio Claver Carrón, a political collector and member of lobby groups, was brought in to replace an official of the Central Intelligence Agency as Director of the Latin American National Security Council, according to the Washington Post. Similarly, Richard Goldberg, an adviser to the Foundation for the Defence of Democracies, has given a key position focusing on Iran. He had Charles Cooperman, a former executive director of the defence industry who once worked for Reagan, appointed deputy national security adviser.
